occurrences.line_text: That Gods and men doe equally adore,
Those Nations farre thy iustice doe adore:
The more would wretched louers her adore.
And her adored with due humblenesse,
That all they as a Goddesse her adoring,
And him adoring as her liues deare Lord,
Adornd with gold and iewels shining cleare,
Adornd with gemmes and owches wondrous faire,
Adornd with fruitfull Oliues all arownd,
Like Phoebus face adornd with sunny rayes,
He doth adorne, and is adorn'd of it
Adorn'd with all diuine perfection,
And both adorn'd with lampes of flaming light,
Adorn'd with honor and all comely grace:
Her selfe, adorn'd with gems and iewels manifold.
Like to the Euening starre adorn'd with deawy ray.
Adornd with goodly gifts of beauties grace,
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
Of all Gods workes, which do this world adorne,
Did decke her, and too lauishly adorne,
This Gardin to adorne with all varietie.
Thy Gransire Nereus promist to adorne?
The girlond of her honour did adorne:
Adorne the world with like to heauenly light,
And Phoebus with faire beames did her adorne,
Without adorne of gold or siluer bright,
Doest fayrest shine, and most adorne thy place,
He doth adorne, and is adorn'd of it
And doe adorne your Court, where courtesies excell.
And lost the crowne, which should my head by right adorne.
Yet full of valour, the which did adorne
To make a garland to adorne her hed,
Hence to professe: for shame is to adorne
As if this to adorne, she all the rest did pill.
Her to adorne, when so she forth doth wend:
Which decke to body or adorne the mynde,
Adorned all with gold, and girlonds gay,
Fairely to rise, and her adorned hed
Goodly adorned, and exceeding faire:
Adorned all with gemmes of endlesse price,
Adornes the person of her Maiestie;
By sweet Clonmell, adornes rich Waterford;
And thicke entangled knots adown does slacke.
That a large purple streme adown their giambeux falles.
Low his lasciuious armes adown did creepe,
Forth spurred fast: adowne his coursers side
Large floods of bloud adowne their sides did raile;
Thrise did she sinke adowne in deadly swownd,
High ouer hils, and low adowne the dale,
And scaly tayle was stretcht adowne his backe full low.
Which hong adowne his side in twisted gold,
Doth roll adowne the rocks, and fall with fearefull drift.
With snowy lockes adowne his shoulders shed,
This said, adowne he looked to the ground,
All night she watcht, ne once adowne would lay
Ne weene my right with strength adowne to tread,
Adowne so fast, and all his armour steepe,
Adowne the rolling riuer she did poure,
Adowne he kest it with so puissant wrest,
Did bow adowne, as ouer-burdened.
Vp in one knot, he low adowne did lose:
That like pure Orient perles adowne it trild,
She with her Nourse adowne to sleepe did lye;
Till thou in open field adowne be smot.
And Penda, seeking him adowne to tread,
Shall tread adowne, and do him fowly dye,
Till faint through irkesome wearinesse, adowne
With that adowne out of her Christall eyne
Dropped adowne vpon her yuorie brest:
Vpbounden, did them selues adowne display,
To looke adowne, or vpward to the hight:
And hong adowne his head, as he did dreame:
Her tender waste was wound, adowne gan fall,
Adowne, as if their springes of life were spent;
Adowne their sides like litle riuers stremed,
Into the Martian field adowne descended,
Adowne her backe, the which it fairely blest
And all adowne their riuen sides did ronne.
Her goodly lockes adowne her backe did flow
Ouer the Castle wall adowne her cast,
By a false trap was let adowne to fall
And with such monstrous poise adowne descended,
Compeld him soone the spoyle adowne to lay.
Vpon the grasse her selfe adowne she layd;
And euen as his right hand adowne descends,
And tooke their gentle offer: so adowne
The sight whereof the Lady sore adrad,
Vpon him set, of perill nought adrad,
And the whole family therewith adred,
And mightie kingdomes of his force adred;
Yet nought thereof was Triamond adredde,
And in frayle wood on Adrian gulfe doth fleet,
That when the knight he spide, he gan aduance
Eftsoones he gan aduance his haughtie crest,
Can high aduance his broad discoloured brest,
That she may thee aduance for workes and merites iust.
To pricke of highest praise forth to aduance,
And to aduance his name and glorie more,
And goodly well aduance, that goodly well was tryde.
Soone after did the brethren three aduance,
To fight with Hercules, that did aduance
True vertue to aduance, shall here recounted bee.
He could aduance, he farre was gone and past.
Proud of such glory and aduancement vaine,
Taking aduantage of his open iaw,
Misfortune waites aduantage to entrap
Making aduantage, to reuenge their spight,
Till that at last, when he aduantage spyde,
And foule aduantage this good Knight dismayd,
Through which aduantage, in his strength he rose,
Now hurtling round aduantage for to take:
Still as aduantage they espyde thereto:
But for aduantage ground vnto him gaue,
To fight in water, great aduantage had,
Weening at last to win aduantage new;
Hauing by chaunce espide aduantage neare,
Taking aduantage, and her yet fresh woes,
Ne for aduantage terme to entertaine,
Yet when as fit aduantage he did spy,
He following that faire aduantage fast,
That meant to make aduantage of his misery.
Hauing by chaunce a close aduantage vew'd,
That at aduantage him at last he tooke,
But wayt aduantage, when they downe did light.
And sold for most aduantage not to be forstalled.
But when she saw the knight his speare aduaunce,
Which being taught, he forward gan aduaunce
How to aduaunce with fauourable hands,
And to his mistresse each himselfe stroue to aduaunce.
And towards gan a deadly shaft aduaunce,
Phedon I hight (quoth he) and do aduaunce
Doth blesse her seruaunts, and them high aduaunce.
Did high aduaunce the crowne of Faery:
His pace he freshly forward did aduaunce,
For that same Brute, whom much he did aduaunce
Did yeeld; Ne lesse the Lady did aduaunce.
Nathlesse with wonted rage he him aduaunced neare.
To see the Redcrosse thus aduaunced hye;
And noble worth to be aduaunced hye:
To th'vpper part, where was aduaunced hye
And high aduaunced crests downe meekely feld,
He should aduaunced be to high regard,
So shall your glory be aduaunced much,
As Ioue will haue aduaunced to the skie,
Ne ought, that did to his aduauncement tend,
Is this thine high aduauncement, ï¿½ is this
Greatly aduauncing his gay cheualree.
And high aduauncing his bloud-thirstie blade,
The same aduauncing high aboue his head,
But had ye then him forth aduauncing seene,
Eftsoones aduauncing that enchaunted shield,
And turning fierce, her speckled taile aduaunst,
And proud Antiochus, the which aduaunst
Sir Terwin hight, that well himselfe aduaunst
When that lewd ribauld with vile lust aduaunst
In the meant marke, aduaunst his shield atweene,
Fiercely aduaunst his valorous right arme,
Thy Loue is there aduaunst to be another Grace.
That in aduauntage would his puissance bost:
That of the time doth dew aduauntage take;
Waiting aduauntage on the pray to sease;
Thereto a great aduauntage eke he has
And watch aduauntage, how to worke his care:
To spy where he may some aduauntage get;
His haughtie courage to aduengement fell:
That battels vtmost triall to aduenter.
Those be the riches fit for an aduent'rous knight.
Aduent'rous knighthood on her selfe to don,
Or by aduentrous marchandize to thriue;
Yet he it oft aduentur'd to inuade.
That could her purchase with his liues aduentur'd gage.
The which I earst aduentur'd for your sake.
Vpon a great aduenture he was bond,
Your first aduenture: many such I pray,
He passed forth, and new aduenture sought;
Was for to seeke aduenture in strange place,
By straunge aduenture as it did betyde,
But what aduenture, or what high intent
Of her aduenture mindfull for to bee.
Th'aduenture of the Errant damozell,
And whither now on new aduenture bound.
Through fortune of his first aduenture faire,
So long he yode, yet no aduenture found,
With hard aduenture, which I haue in hand,
What straunge aduenture do ye now pursew?
Him selfe addrest to that aduenture hard:
So hard a workmanship aduenture darre,
Whom straunge aduenture did from Britaine fet,
Great hazard were it, and aduenture fond,
Dare not aduenture on the stubborne pray,
Ne durst aduenture rashly in to wend,
That suddein change she strange aduenture thought.
With silly Virgin by aduenture brought
As if he were on some aduenture bent,
And afterwardes, on what aduenture now he rode.
As on aduenture by the way he past:
At wilde aduenture, like a forlorne weft,
So forth he rode, as his aduenture fell;
By great aduenture trauelled that way;
Which faire aduenture when Cambello spide,
Vpon her first aduenture forth did ride,
Vpon an hard aduenture yet in quest,
All that aduenture, which ye did assay
So on that hard aduenture forth I went,
An hard aduenture, which did then befall,
And wend with him on his aduenture hard.
We on his first aduenture may him forward send.
Vppon his first aduenture, which him forth did call.
But by aduenture found them faring so,
A straunge aduenture, which not farre thence lay;
To graunt him that aduenture for his former feat.
But on his first aduenture forward forth did ride.
Vppon an hard aduenture sore bestad,
On his aduenture, vowing not to start,
And heare th'aduenture of her late mischaunce;
An hard aduenture with vnhappie end;
Ne wight with him on that aduenture went,
Were glad to heare of that aduenture new,
A great aduenture, which did him from them deuide.
That as I late aduentured for your sake,
He is a great aduenturer, (said he)
Of straunge aduentures, which abroad did pas.
And far abroad for straunge aduentures sought:
After long labours and aduentures spent,
Tydings of warre, and of aduentures new;
But warres, nor new aduentures none he herd.
But forward fare, as their aduentures fell,
Of tydings strange, and of aduentures rare:
Of straunge aduentures, and of perils sad,
Whiles they his pittifull aduentures heard,
The braue aduentures of this Faery knight
As wont ye knights to seeke aduentures wilde,
Which he by many rash aduentures wan,
Resort, to heare of straunge aduentures to be told.
Seeking for daunger and aduentures vaine?
And seeke aduentures, as he with Prince Arthur went.
And many hard aduentures did atchieue;
Seeking aduentures hard, to exercise
To hunt out perils and aduentures hard,
And many straunge aduentures to be fond,
To seeke aduentures, which mote him befall,
Did get through great aduentures by him donne:
That raungd abroad to seeke aduentures wilde,
A long discourse of his aduentures vaine,
And great adue[n]tures found, that now were lo[n]g to sayne.
And hard aduentures twixt themselues alone,
Seeking aduentures in the saluage wood,
Seeking aduentures, where they anie knew.
And strange aduentures, all the way they rode:
The hard aduentures and strange haps to tell;
Mongst Knights, when on aduentures they did ride,
Seeking aduentures, where he mote heare tell;
And pant with hope of that aduentures hap:
To follow his aduentures first intent,
Through hard aduentures deedes of armes to try,
Consisted much in that aduentures priefe.
Through other great aduentures hethertoo
And of aduentures, which had in his measure
His long aduentures gan to him relate,
After aduentures, where they mote them get.
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
Thy life and honour late aduenturest,
Them to disable from reuenge aduenturing.
Full many knights aduenturous and stout
Which haue full many feats aduenturous
Vnto those knights aduenturous, to tell
Like knight aduenturous in outward vew,
Had him misfalne in his aduenturous quest;
All noble Knights, which were aduenturous,
Blew vp a bitter storme of foule aduersity.
Stood in the preasse close couered, well aduewed,
Mishaps are maistred by aduice discrete,
With temperate aduice discounselled,
Is wisely to aduise: now day is spent;
He stayde his hand, and gan himselfe aduise
And oft for dread of hurt would him aduise,
But mote I wisely you aduise to doon;
Dotard (said he) let be thy deepe aduise;
And in your selfe do not the same aduise?
By whose aduise old Priams cittie fell,
By their aduise, and her owne wicked wit,
All trauellers; therefore aduise ye well,
Of life it be, then better doe aduise.
He gan aduise how best he mote darrayne
At whose request he gan him selfe aduise
And better bad aduise, ere they assaid
Goe now, Clarinda, well thy wits aduise,
She stayd not to aduise which way to take;
Right well Sir knight ye haue aduised bin,
Certes me seemes bene not aduised well,
With goodly counsell and aduisement right;
She oft and oft aduiz'd him to refraine
Be well aduiz'd, that he stand stedfast still:
She was by him aduiz'd, to send me quight
He would no longer stay him to aduize,
As that your daughter can ye well aduize,
But let that man with better sence aduize,
The next could of things present best aduize;
For thy he gan some other wayes aduize,
And therefore gan aduize with her old Squire,
It's late in death of daunger to aduize,
Gan to aduize, what best were to be done.
The best (sayd he) that I can you aduize,
But them the Priest rebuking, did aduize
Tho gan Sir Calidore him to aduize
And bids thee be aduized for the best,
Then why doest not, thou ill aduized man,
And strong aduizement of six wisards old,
Tempring the passion with aduizement slow,
Perhaps my succour, or aduizement meete
The best aduizement was of bad, to let her
He looked backe, and her aduizing well,
Euen foule Adulterie her face before,
Rose many aduocates for her to plead:
Could terrifie from Fortunes faire adward:
Through the AEgaean seas from Pirates vew,
As was Aegerie, that Numa tought;
And like a fire, when he Aegin' assayd:
With timely pride aboue the Aegyptian vale,
Amid th'AegÃ¦an sea long time did stray,
I rest his wretched thrall, the sad AEmylia.
Ah sad AEmylia (then sayd Amoret,)
Then forth the sad AEmylia issewed,
AEmylia and Amoret abode,
Whom soone as faire AEmylia beheld,
What to Aeneas fell; sith that men sayne
And blustring AEolus his boasted sire,
Nor Aeolus sharp blast could worke them any wrong.
And all his windes Dan Aeolus did keepe,
And Aeolus faire daughter Arne hight.
As when Dan AEolus in great displeasure,
From off the earth to take his aerie flight.
Or aerie spirit vnder false pretence,
His aery plumes doth rouze, full rudely dight,
And nothing left, but like an aery Spright,
But Herebus sonne of Aeternitie is hight.
More whot, then Aetn', or flaming Mongiball:
Like an huge Aetn' of deepe engulfed griefe,
As burning Aetna from his boyling stew
That it in flames of Aetna wrought apart,
Was fowly dight, and he of death afeard.
But lookt on Glauce grim, who woxe afeard
Against him stoutly ran, as nought afeard,
Nether of enuy, nor of chaunge afeard,
With those two Carles, fled fast away, afeard
In all affaires, and was both bold and free,
And wondrous wit to menage high affaires,
Of straunge affaires, and noble hardiment,
Welds kingdomes causes, & affaires of state,
She was about affaires of common wele,
Therefore the Prince, whom great affaires in mynd
Him all amazd, and almost made affeard:
I hid my selfe from it, as one affeard;
Vp to the skyes, that them of drowning made affeard.
Or keepe their cabins: much I am affeard,
Yet flyes away of her owne feet affeard,
She went in perill, of each noyse affeard,
And fresh assayld his foe; who halfe affeard
The whiles faire Amoret, of nought affeard,
To sincke into his sence, nor mind affect,
All ouercome with infinite affect,
His deare affect with silence did restraine,
From that they most affect, and in due termes containe.
From that day forth she gan him to affect,
As diuerse wits affected diuers beene.
Ne lesse was she in secret hart affected,
Gan weepe and wayle, as if great griefe had her affected.
For from those outward sences ill affected,
And drizling teares did shed for pure affection.
(Entire affection hateth nicer hands)
Till ruth and fraile affection did constraine,
Sir Guyon more affection to increace,
Who glad t'embosome his affection vile,
His hart with great affection was embayd,
Who with entire affection him receau'd,
Through goodly temperance, and affection chaste,
But this affection nothing straunge I find;
Affection, I doe languish and expire.
And curteise vse conceiu'd affection bace,
He ween'd that his affection entire
Of huge affection, did in pleasure melt,
Ne naturall affection faultlesse blame,
More franke affection did to her afford,
Albee in heart he like affection fond,
Ne euer was with fond affection moued,
And with so firme affection were allyde,
And now t'increase affection naturall,
Profest to her true friendship and affection sweet.
And friendship, which a faint affection breeds
Ne thinke th'affection of her hart to draw
Her graunted loue, but with affection cold
The deare affection vnto kindred sweet,
For naturall affection soone doth cesse,
The course of loose affection to forstall,
And gan thenceforth to cast affection,
And touched with intire affection, nigh him drew.
For deare affection and vnfayned zeale,
And deare affection of so dolefull dreare,
But with entire affection and appearaunce plaine.
From things, that stirre vp fraile affection;
And him bewayling with affection base,
Then each to other well affectionate,
Each others griefe with zeale affectionate,
And Lodestarre of all chaste affectione,
That to affections does the bridle lend;
As that, which strong affections do apply
That as the one stird vp affections bace,
Let not her fault your sweet affections marre,
Not that same, which doth base affections moue
And loose affections streightly to restraine;
Affiance made, my happinesse begonne,
He was affiaunced long time before,
He though affide vnto a former loue,
By Marinell, was vnto him affide,
And ioyd that euer she affixed had,
But double griefs afflict concealing harts,
All night afflict thy naturall repose,
And secretly afflict with iealous feare,
And inly did afflict her pensiue thought,
Doe them afflict, which no man can appease,
The argument of mine afflicted stile:
To succour the weake state of sad afflicted Troy.
Lowde shriking him afflicted to the very sowle.
And whom he list reserue, to be afflicted more.
And to afflicted minds sweet rest and quiet sends.
The which afflicted his engrieued mind;
To whom complayning her afflicted plight,
Else should afflicted wights oftimes despeire.
Her selfe there close afflicted long in vaine,
Him still reuiling and afflicting sore,
Should plonged be in such affliction,
On faire Irene in her affliction,
And euer more and more her owne affliction wrought.
Without affliction or disquietnesse,
And day and night afflicts with mortall paine,
And made there to abound with lauish affluence.
Ne would for price, or prayers once affoord,
Of that faire Castle to affoord them vew;
To him did open, and affoorded way;
And doen the heauens afford him vitall food?
And Archimage besought, him that afford,
Thou her afford, full shortly I her dead shall see.
Thus much afford me, ere that he did die
Would me refuse their pledges to afford,
That least auantage mote to him afford,
More franke affection did to her afford,
Or what good fortune did to him afford,
Ne other end their fury would afford,
To bide what iudgement ye shall vs afford.
To be her thrall, and seruice her afford.
All times haue wont safe passage to afford
Through promise to afford her timely aide,
But to the shamefull doer it afford.
That should to me such curtesie afford,
Which if they would afford him ayde at need
To graunt him fauour, or afford him loue.
Affraid, least to themselues the like mishappen might.
Ne yet of present perill be affraid;
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
Was fled afore, affraid of him, as feend of hell.
For he was much affraid, himselfe alone to find.
That all his many it affraide did make:
They bene ymet, both readie to affrap,
To tossen speare and shield, and to affrap
Who full of ghastly fright and cold affray,
And souce so sore, that they the heauens affray:
With which her yron wheeles did them affray,
Or when the flying heauens he would affray;
And courage fierce, that all men did affray,
She, that base Braggadochio did affray,
Seemed to thunder, and did nigh affray
And afterwardes affray with cruell threat,
When as he saw the mercilesse affray
The feare whereof seem'd much her to affray:
Full many did affray, that else faine enter would.
The dreadfull sight did them so sore affray,
And with vnwonted terror halfe affray,
For all her other children, through affray,
As if that there were some tumultuous affray.
And made to fly, like doues, whom the Eagle doth affray.
And well approu'd in batteilous affray,
Who comming forth yet full of late affray,
What frayes ye, that were wont to comfort me affrayd?
Had her abandond. She of nought affrayd,
Wherewith the stiffe beame quaked, as affrayd,
And saw no meanes to scape, of shame affrayd,
The cloudes, as things affrayd, before him flye;
Of euery finest fingers touch affrayd;
Of much more vncouth thing I was affrayd;
That fast she from him fled, no lesse affrayd,
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
Whereat she sore affrayd, yet her besought
And lightly started vp as one affrayd;
Its best to hope the best, though of the worst affrayd.
All loued vertue, no man was affrayd
But like as one, whom feends had made affrayd,
But when the villaine saw her so affrayd,
He therewith much abashed and affrayd,
The mightie ones, affrayd of euery chaunges dread.
And who sees not, would be affrayd to heare:
